The '''Rashba effect''', also called '''Bychkov-Rashba effect''', is a momentum-dependent splitting of [[Spin (physics)|spin]] bands in bulk [[crystal]]s<ref group="note">More specifically, uniaxial noncentrosymmetric crystals.</ref> and low-dimensional [[condensed matter]] systems (such as [[heterostructure]]s and [[surface states]]) similar to the splitting of [[particle]]s and [[anti-particle]]s in the [[Dirac equation|Dirac]] Hamiltonian. The splitting is a combined effect of [[spin–orbit interaction]] and asymmetry of the crystal potential, in particular in the direction perpendicular to the two-dimensional plane (as applied to surfaces and heterostructures). This effect is named in honour of [[Emmanuel Rashba]], who discovered it with Valentin I. Sheka in 1959 <ref>E. I. Rashba and V. I. Sheka, Fiz. Tverd. Tela - Collected Papers (Leningrad), v.II, 162-176 (1959) (in Russian), English translation: Supplemental Material to the paper by G. Bihlmayer, O. Rader, and R. Winkler, Focus on the Rashba effect, New J. Phys. '''17''', 050202 (2015).</ref> for three-dimensional systems and afterward with Yurii A. Bychkov in 1984 for two-dimensional systems.<ref>Yu. A. Bychkov and E. I. Rashba, Properties of a 2D electron gas with a lifted spectrum degeneracy, Sov. Phys. - JETP Lett. '''39''', 78-81 (1984)</ref><ref>G. Bihlmayer, O. Rader and R. Winkler, Focus on the Rashba effect , New J. Phys. '''17''', 050202 (2015)</ref><ref>Han Woong Yeom and Marco Grioni, eds, Special issue on electron spectroscopy for Rashba spin-orbit interaction, Journal of Electron Spectroscopy and Related Phenomena, '''201''', 1-126 (2015)</ref> Both the Rashba and [[Dresselhaus effect|Dresselhaus]] effects are concepts of the [[PhySH Physics Subject Headlines]] scheme.
Remarkably, this effect can drive a wide variety of novel physical phenomena, especially operating electron spins by electric fields, even when it is a small correction to the band structure of the two-dimensional metallic state. An examples of a physical phenomena that can be explained by Rashba model is the anisotropic [[magnetoresistance]] (AMR).<ref group="note">AMR in most common magnetic materials was reviewed by {{Harvard citation no brackets|McGuire|Potter|1975|}}. A more recent work ({{Harvard citation no brackets|Schliemann|Loss|2003}}) focused on the possibility of Rashba-effect-induced AMR and some extensions and corrections were given later ({{Harvard citation no brackets|Trushin|Výborný|Moraczewski|Kovalev|2009}}).</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last=McGuire|first=T.|author2=Potter|first2=R.|date=|year=1975|title=Anisotropic magnetoresistance in ferromagnetic 3d alloys|url=|journal=IEEE Transactions on Magnetics|volume=11|issue=4|pages=1018–1038|bibcode=1975ITM....11.1018M|doi=10.1109/TMAG.1975.1058782|ref=harv|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite journal|last=Schliemann|first=John|author2=Loss|first2=Daniel|date=|year=2003|title=Anisotropic transport in a two-dimensional electron gas in the presence of spin-orbit coupling|url=|journal=Physical Review B|volume=68|page=165311|pages=|arxiv=cond-mat/0306528|bibcode=2003PhRvB..68p5311S|doi=10.1103/physrevb.68.165311|ref=harv|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Trushin|first=Maxim|last2=Výborný|first2=Karel|last3=Moraczewski|first3=Peter|last4=Kovalev|first4=Alexey A.|last5=Schliemann|first5=John|last6=Jungwirth|first6=T.|date=2009|title=Anisotropic magnetoresistance of spin-orbit coupled carriers scattered from polarized magnetic impurities|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.80.134405|journal=Physical Review B|volume=80|issue=13|pages=134405|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.80.134405|ref=harv|via=|arxiv=0904.3785}}</ref>
Additionally, superconductors with large Rashba splitting are suggested as possible realizations of the elusive [[Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov phase|Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov]] (FFLO) state<ref>{{cite journal|last=Agterberg|first=Daniel|title=Anisotropic magnetoresistance of spin-orbit coupled carriers scattered from polarized magnetic impurities|journal=Physica C|year=2003|volume=387|issue=1-2|pages=13–16|bibcode = 2003PhyC..387...13A |doi = 10.1016/S0921-4534(03)00634-8 }}</ref>, [[Majorana fermion]]s and [[topological p-wave superconductor]]s.<ref name="SF">{{cite journal|author1=Sato, Masatoshi |author2=Fujimoto, Satoshi |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Topological phases of noncentrosymmetric superconductors: Edge states, Majorana fermions, and non-Abelian statistics| journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 79| pages = 094504| year = 2009| doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.79.094504| url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.79.094504| |arxiv = 0811.3864 |bibcode = 2009PhRvB..79i4504S }}</ref><ref name="PW">{{cite journal|last=V. Mourik, K. Zuo1, S. M. Frolov, S. R. Plissard, E. P. A. M. Bakkers and L. P. Kouwenhoven|title=Signatures of Majorana Fermions in Hybrid Superconductor-Semiconductor Nanowire Devices|journal=Science Express|year=2012|volume=1222360|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/2012/04/11/science.1222360.abstract?sid=4c749b29-f934-48db-acea-b426648da71f|doi=10.1126/science.1222360|arxiv = 1204.2792 |bibcode = 2012Sci...336.1003M|pages=1003–1007}}</ref>
Lately, a momentum dependent pseudospin-orbit coupling has been realized in cold atom systems.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lin|first=Y.-J. |author2=K. Jiménez-García |author3=I. B. Spielman|title= Spin-orbit-coupled Bose-Einstein condensates|journal=Nature|year=2011|volume=471|pages=83–86|arxiv = 1103.3522 |bibcode = 2011Natur.471...83L |doi = 10.1038/nature09887 }}</ref>
==Hamiltonian== The Rashba effect is most easily seen in the simple model Hamiltonian known as the Rashba Hamiltonian :<math> H_{\rm R}=\alpha(\boldsymbol{\sigma}\times\mathbf{p})\cdot \hat{z} </math>, where <math>\alpha</math> is the Rashba coupling, <math>\boldsymbol p</math> is the [[momentum]] and <math>\boldsymbol \sigma</math> is the [[Pauli matrix]] vector. This is nothing but a two-dimensional version of the Dirac Hamiltonian (with a 90 degrees rotation of the spins).
The Rashba model in solids can be derived in the framework of the [[k·p perturbation theory]] <ref>{{cite book|last=Winkler|first=Ronald|title=Spin-orbit Coupling Effects in Two-Dimensional Electron and Hole Systems|publisher=Springer Tracts in Modern Physics|location=New-York|url=http://www.physics.udel.edu/~bnikolic/QTTG/NOTES/SPINTRONICS/WINKLER=spin_orbit_coupling_effect_in_2d_electron_and_hole_systems.pdf}}</ref> or from the point of view of a [[tight binding]] approximation.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=L. Petersena |author2=P. Hedegård |lastauthoramp=yes |title=A simple tight-binding model of spin–orbit splitting of sp-derived surface states|journal=Surface Science|year=2000|volume=459|issue=1-2|pages=49–56|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0039602800004416|doi=10.1016/S0039-6028(00)00441-6|bibcode=2000SurSc.459...49P}}</ref> However, the specifics of these methods are considered tedious and many prefer an intuitive toy model that gives qualitatively the same physics (quantitatively it gives a poor estimation of the coupling <math display="inline">\alpha</math>). Here we will introduce the intuitive [[toy model]] approach followed by a sketch of a more accurate derivation.
== Naive derivation== The Rashba effect is a direct result of inversion symmetry breaking in the direction perpendicular to the two-dimensional plane. Therefore, let us add to the [[Hamiltonian function|Hamiltonian]] a term that breaks this symmetry in the form of an electric field :<math> H_E= - E_0 z </math>, Due to relativistic corrections an electron moving with velocity '''''v''''' in the electric field will experience an effective magnetic field '''''B''''' :<math> \mathbf{B}=-(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{E})/c^2 </math>, where <math>c</math> is the speed of light. This magnetic field couples to the electron spin :<math> H_{\mathrm{SO}}=\frac{g\mu_{\rm B}}{2c^2}(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{E})\cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma} </math>, where <math>-g\mu_{\rm B} \mathbf{\sigma}/2</math> is the [[electron magnetic moment]].
Within this toy model, the Rashba Hamiltonian is given by :<math> H_{\mathrm{R}}=\alpha(\boldsymbol{\sigma}\times\mathbf{p})\cdot \hat{z}</math>, where <math>\alpha=\frac{g\mu_{\rm B}E_0}{2mc^2}</math>. However, while this "toy model" is superficially convincing, the [[Ehrenfest theorem]] seems to suggest that since the electronic motion in the <math>\hat{z}</math> direction is that of a bound state that confines it to the 2D surface, the time-averaged electric field (i.e., including that of the potential that binds it to the 2D surface) that the electron experiences must be zero! When applied to the toy model, this argument seems to rule out the Rashba effect (and caused much controversy prior to its experimental confirmation), but turns out to be subtly-incorrect when applied to a more realistic model.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=P. Pfeffer |author2=W. Zawadzki |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Spin splitting of conduction subbands in III-V heterostructures due to inversion asymmetry|journal=Physical Review B|year=1999|volume=59|pages=R5312-5315|bibcode = 1999PhRvB..59.5312P |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.59.R5312 }}</ref>. While the above naive derivation provides correct analytical form of the Rashba Hamiltonian, it is inconsistent because the effect comes from mixing energy bands (interband matrix elements) rather from intraband term of the naive model. Consistent approach explains large magnitude of the effect that includes in the denominator instead of the [[Dirac]] gap of <math>mc^2</math> of the order of MeV combination of splittings the energy bands in a crystal that are about eV, see next section.
== Estimation of the Rashba coupling in a realistic system – the tight binding approach== In this section we will sketch a method to estimate the coupling constant <math>\alpha</math> from microscopics using a tight-binding model. Typically, the itinerant electrons that form the two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) originate in atomic '''''s''''' and '''''p''''' orbitals. For the sake of simplicity let's consider holes in the <math>p_z</math> band.<ref>Typically in semiconductors the Rashba splitting is considered for the '''''s''''' band around the <math>\Gamma_6</math> point. In the discussion above we consider only the mixing of the anti-bonding '''''p''''' bands. However, the induced Rashba splitting is simply given by the hybridization between '''''p''''' and '''''s''''' bands. Therefore, this discussion is actually all one needs to understand the Rashba splitting at near the <math>\Gamma_6</math> point.</ref> In this picture electrons fill all the <math>p</math> states except for a few holes near the <math>\Gamma</math> point.
The necessary ingredients to get Rashba splitting are atomic spin-orbit coupling :<math> H_{\mathrm{SO}}=\Delta_{\mathrm{SO}} \mathbf{L} \otimes \boldsymbol{\sigma} </math>, and an asymmetric potential in the direction perpendicular to the 2D surface :<math> H_{E}=E_0 \,z </math>,
The main effect of the symmetry breaking potential is to open a band gap <math>\Delta_{\mathrm{BG}}</math> between the isotropic <math>p_z</math> and the <math>p_x</math>, <math>p_y</math> bands. The secondary effect of this potential is that it [[Orbital hybridisation|hybridizes]] the <math>p_z</math> with the <math>p_x</math> and <math>p_y</math> bands. This hybridization can be understood within a tight-binding approximation. The hopping element from a <math>p_z</math> state at site <math>i</math> with spin <math>\sigma</math> to a <math>p_{x}</math> or <math>p_{y}</math> state at site j with spin <math>\sigma'</math> is given by
:<math> t_{ij;\sigma \sigma'}^{x,y}=\langle p_z,i;\sigma | H | p_{x,y},j ;\sigma'\rangle </math>, where <math>H</math> is the total Hamiltonian. In the absence of a symmetry breaking field, i.e. <math>H_E= 0</math>, the hopping element vanishes due to symmetry. However, if <math>H_E\ne 0</math> then the hopping element is finite. For example, the nearest neighbor hopping element is :<math> t_{\sigma \sigma'} ^{x,y}=E_0 \langle p_z,i ;\sigma| z | p_{x,y},i+1_{x,y} ;\sigma'\rangle = t_0 \,\mathrm{sgn}(1_{x,y}) \delta_{\sigma \sigma'}</math>, where <math>1_{x,y}</math> stands for unit distance in the <math>x,y</math> direction respectively and <math>\delta_{\sigma \sigma'}</math> is [[Kronecker delta|Kronecker's delta]].
The Rashba effect can be understood as a second order perturbation theory in which a spin-up hole, for example, jumps from a <math>|p_z,i;\uparrow\rangle</math> state to a <math>|p_{x,y},i+1_{x,y};\uparrow\rangle</math> with amplitude <math>t_0</math> then uses the spin[[spin–orbit interaction|–]]<nowiki/>orbit coupling to flip spin and go back down to the <math>|p_z,i+1_{x,y};\downarrow\rangle</math> with amplitude <math>\Delta_{\mathrm{SO}}</math>. Note that overall the hole hopped one site and flipped spin. The energy denominator in this perturbative picture is of course <math>\Delta_{\mathrm{BG}}</math> such that all together we have :<math> \alpha\approx {a \,t_0 \,\Delta_{\mathrm{SO}}\over \Delta_{\mathrm{BG}}} </math>, where <math>a</math> is the interionic distance. This result is typically several orders of magnitude larger than the naive result derived in the previous section.
==Application== ''[[Spintronics]]'' - Electronic devices are based on the ability to manipulate the electrons position by means of electric fields. Similarly, devices can be based on the manipulation of the spin degree of freedom. The Rashba effect allows to manipulate the spin by the same means, that is, without the aid of a magnetic field. Such devices have many advantages over their electronic counterparts.<ref>D. Bercioux and P. Lucignano, Quantum transport in Rashba spin–orbit materials: a review, Rep. Prog. Phys. '''78''', 106001 (2015); https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.00570.</ref><ref>[http://www.spintronics-info.com/electron-spin-splitting-rashba-effect-shown-bismuth-selenide Rashba Effect in Spintronic Devices]</ref>
''[[Topological quantum computation]]'' - Lately it has been suggested that the Rashba effect can be used to realize a p-wave superconductor.<ref name="SF" /><ref name="PW" /> Such a superconductor has very special [[edge-states]] which are known as [[Majorana fermion|Majorana bound states]]. The non-locality immunizes them to local scattering and henceforth they are predicted to have long [[coherence (physics)|coherence]] times. Decoherence is one of the largest barriers on the way to realize a full scale [[quantum computer]] and these immune states are therefore considered good candidates for a [[qubit|quantum bit]].
Discovery of '''giant Rashba effect''' in bulk crystals such as BiTeI<ref>K.Ishizaka, K. Ishizaka, M. S. Bahramy, H. Murakawa, M. Sakano, T. Shimojima, T. Sonobe, K. Koizumi,S. Shin, H. Miyahara, A. Kimura, K. Miyamoto, T. Okuda, H. Namatame, M. Taniguchi, R. Arita, N. Nagaosa, K. Kobayashi, Y. Murakami, R. Kumai, Y. Kaneko, Y. Onose, and Y. Tokura, "Giant Rashba-type spin splitting in bulk BiTeI", Nature materials '''10''', 521-526 (2011).</ref> and ferroelectric GeTe<ref>D. Di Sante, P. Barone, R. Bertacco, and S. Picozzi, Electric Control of the Giant Rashba Effect in Bulk GeTe, Advanced Materials, '''25''', 509-513 (2013).</ref> and in a number of low-dimensional systems bears a promise of creating devices operating electrons spins at nanoscale and possessing short operational times.
== Dresselhaus spin[[spin–orbit interaction|–]]<nowiki/>orbit coupling == {{main|Dresselhaus effect}}
The Rashba spin-orbit coupling is typical for systems with uniaxial symmetry, e.g., for hexagonal crystals of CdS and CdSe for which it was originally found <ref>E. I. Rashba and V. I. Sheka, Fiz. Tverd. Tela - Collected Papers (Leningrad), v.II, 162-176 (1959) (in Russian), English translation: Supplemental Material to the paper by G. Bihlmayer, O. Rader, and R. Winkler, Focus on the Rashba effect, New J. Phys. '''17''', 050202 (2015).</ref> and perovskites, and also for heterostructures where it develops as a result of a symmetry breaking field in the direction perpendicular to the 2D surface.<ref>Yu. A. Bychkov and E. I. Rashba, Properties of a 2D electron gas with a lifted spectrum degeneracy, Sov. Phys. - JETP Lett. '''39''', 78-81 (1984)</ref> All these systems lack inversion symmetry. A similar effect, known as the Dresselhaus spin orbit coupling<ref>G. Dresselhaus, Spin-Orbit Coupling Effects in Zinc Blende Structures, Phys. Rev. '''100''', 580 (1955)</ref> arises in cubic crystals of A<sub>III</sub>B<sub>V</sub> type lacking inversion symmetry and in [[quantum well]]s manufactured from them.

A '''reversible hydrogen electrode''' ('''RHE''') is a [[reference electrode]], more specifically a subtype of the [[standard hydrogen electrode]]s, for [[electrochemical]] processes. Unlike the standard hydrogen electrode, its measured [[potential]] does not change with the [[pH]], so it can be directly used in the electrolyte.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jp037126d |title=The reversible hydrogen electrode: potential-dependent activation energies over platinum from quantum theory|year=2004|last1=Cai|first1=Yu|last2=Anderson|first2=Alfred B.|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|volume=108|issue=28|pages=9829}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Staehler, M. |author2=Wipperman, K. |author3=Stolten, D. |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.electrochem.org/dl/ma/206/pdfs/1863.pdf |title=Instabilities of the reversible hydrogen reference electrode in direct methanol fuel cells|journal=2004 Joint International Meeting of the Electrochemical Society, abstract 1863}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|jstor=84265 |title=Hydrogen overvoltage|author1=MacInnes, Duncan A. |author2=Adler, Leon |lastauthoramp=yes |pmc=1091559|pmid=16576366|year=1919|volume=5|issue=5|pages=160–3|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|doi=10.1073/pnas.5.5.160|bibcode=1919PNAS....5..160M}}</ref>
The name refers to the fact that the electrode is in the actual electrolyte solution and not separated by a [[salt bridge]]. The hydrogen ion concentration is therefore not 1, but corresponds to that of the electrolyte solution; in this way we can achieve a stable potential with a changing pH value. The potential of the RHE correlates to the pH value: :<math>E_0 = 0.000 - 0.059\times\mathrm{pH}</math>
In general, for hydrogen electrodes in which the reaction:
:<chem> {2H3O+} + {2e^-} <=> {H2} + {2H2O}</chem>
expires, the following dependence of the [[Chemical equilibrium|equilibrium]] potential {{mvar|E}}, hydrogen pressure <math chem>p\ce{[H2]}</math> and the activity <math chem>a\ce{[H3O+]}</math> of the [[hydronium]] ions:
:<math chem> E = E_{00} + \frac{R\;T}{F} \left( \ln \left( a[\ce{H3O+}] \right) - \tfrac{1}{2}\ln\left( \;p[\ce{H2}] \right) \right)</math>
Here <math>E_{00}</math> is the standard reduction potential (this is by definition equal to zero), R is the [[universal gas constant]], T the [[absolute temperature]] and F is the [[Faraday constant]].
Surges occur in the [[electrolysis of water]] which means that the required [[cell voltage]] due to kinetic inhibition is higher than the equilibrium potential. The voltage increases with increasing current density at the electrodes. The measurement of equilibrium potentials is therefore possible without power.
==Principle== The reversible hydrogen electrode is a fairly practical and reproducible electrode "standard." The term refers to a hydrogen electrode immersed in the electrolyte solution actually used.
The benefit of that electrode is that no [[salt bridge]] is needed: * no contamination of the electrolyte by Cl<sup>−</sup> or SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> * no diffusion potentials at the electrolyte bridge ([[liquid junction potential]]). This is important at temperature different to 25 °C. * long time measurements possible (no electrolyte bridge means no maintenance of the bridge)
==See also== *[[Dynamic hydrogen electrode]] *[[Palladium-hydrogen electrode]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} The '''Staebler–Wronski Effect''' (SWE) refers to light-induced [[metastability|metastable]] changes in the properties of hydrogenated [[amorphous silicon]].
The defect density of hydrogenated [[amorphous silicon]] (a-Si:H) increases with light exposure, causing an increase in the [[carrier generation and recombination|recombination current]] and reducing the efficiency of the conversion of [[sunlight]] into [[electricity]].
It was discovered by [[David L. Staebler]] and [[Christopher R. Wronski]] in 1977. They showed that the [[dark current (physics)|dark current]] and [[photoconductivity]] of hydrogenated [[amorphous silicon]] can be reduced significantly by prolonged illumination with intense light. However, on heating the samples to above 150 °C, they could reverse the effect.<ref name="StaeblerWronski1977">{{cite journal|last1=Staebler|first1=D. L.|last2=Wronski|first2=C. R.|title=Reversible conductivity changes in discharge-produced amorphous Si|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=31|issue=4|year=1977|pages=292|issn=0003-6951|doi=10.1063/1.89674|bibcode = 1977ApPhL..31..292S }}</ref>
==Explanation==
===Some experimental results===
* Photoconductivity and dark conductivity decrease rapidly at first before stabilizing at a lower value. * Interruptions in the illumination has no effect on the subsequent rate of change. Once the sample is illuminated again, the photoconductivity will drop as though there was no interruption.
===Suggested explanations=== The exact nature and cause of the Staebler–Wronski effect is still not well known. [[Nanocrystalline silicon]] suffers less from the Staebler–Wronski effect than amorphous silicon, suggesting that the disorder in the amorphous silicon Si network plays a major role. Other properties that could play a role are hydrogen concentration and its complex bonding mechanism, as well as the concentration of impurities.
Historically, the most favored model has been the hydrogen bond switching model.<ref name="Kołodziej2004">{{cite journal |last=Kołodziej |first=A. |date=2004 |title=Staebler-Wronski effect in amorphous silicon and its alloys |url=https://www.infona.pl/resource/bwmeta1.element.baztech-article-BWA1-0005-0076 |journal=Opto-Electronics Review |publisher= |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=21–32 |access-date=31 October 2015}}</ref> It proposes that an electron-hole pair formed by the incident light may recombine near a weak Si–Si bond, releasing energy sufficient to break the bond. A neighbouring H atom then forms a new bond with one of the Si atoms, leaving a [[dangling bond]]. These dangling bonds can trap electron-hole pairs, thus reducing the current that can pass through. However, new experimental evidence is casting doubt on this model. More recently, the ''H collision model'' proposed that two spatially separated recombination events cause emission of mobile hydrogen from Si–H bonds to form two dangling bonds, with a metastable paired H state binding the hydrogen atoms at a distant site.<ref>H.M. Branz, The hydrogen collision model: Quantitative description of metastability in amorphous silicon, Phys. Rev. B, '''59''' 5498, 1999.</ref>
==Effects== The efficiency of an amorphous silicon solar cell typically drops during the first six months of operation. This drop may be in the range from 10% up to 30% depending on the material quality and device design. Most of this loss comes in the [[Fill factor (solar cell)|fill factor]] of the cell. After this initial drop, the effect reaches an equilibrium and causes little further degradation. The equilibrium level shifts with [[operating temperature]] so that performance of modules tend to recover some in the summer months and drop again in the winter months.<ref>Uchida,Y and Sakai,H. Light Induced Effects in a-Si:H Films and Solar Cells, Mat. Res. Soc. Symp. Proc., Vol. 70,1986</ref> Most commercially available a-Si modules have SWE degradation in the 10–15% range and suppliers typically specify efficiency based on performance after the SWE degradation has stabilized. In a typical [[amorphous silicon]] solar cell the efficiency is reduced by up to 30% in the first 6 months as a result of the Staebler–Wronski effect, and the fill factor falls from over 0.7 to about 0.6. This light induced degradation is the major disadvantage of amorphous silicon as a [[photovoltaic]] material.<ref>Nelson, Jenny (2003). ''The Physics of Solar Cells''. Imperial College Press.</ref>
==Methods of reducing the SWE== *Using [[nanocrystalline silicon]] instead of [[amorphous silicon]] *Operating at a higher temperature. This can be accomplished by integrating the PV in a [[photovoltaic thermal hybrid solar collector]] (PVT). *Stacking one or more thinner layers of amorphous silicon together with other materials to form a [[multijunction solar cell]].<ref>[http://photochemistry.epfl.ch/EDEY/B_Strahm.ppt Staebler-Wronski effect in amorphous silicon PV and procedures to limit degradation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306163152/http://photochemistry.epfl.ch/EDEY/B_Strahm.ppt |date=6 March 2007 }}, EY-1.1: 28 October 2005, Benjamin Strahm, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Centre de Recherches en Physique des Plasmas(Power Point Slide Show)</ref> The higher electric field which applies in the thinner layers appears to reduce the SWE.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Hybrid Power System.gif|320px|thumb|Schematics of a hybrid system]]
A '''stand-alone power system''' ('''SAPS''' or '''SPS'''), also known as '''remote area power supply''' ('''RAPS'''), is an [[off-the-grid]] [[electricity]] system for locations that are not fitted with an [[electricity distribution]] system. Typical SAPS include one or more methods of [[electricity generation]], [[Grid energy storage|energy storage]], and regulation.
Electricity is typically generated by one or more of the following methods: * [[Photovoltaic system]] using [[Photovoltaic module|solar panel]]s * [[Wind turbine]] * [[Geothermal]] source * [[Micro combined heat and power]] * [[Micro hydro]] * [[Diesel generator|Diesel]] or [[biofuel]] generator * [[Thermoelectric generator]] (TEGs)
Storage is typically implemented as a [[Battery (electricity)|battery bank]], but other solutions exist including [[fuel cell]]s. Power drawn directly from the battery will be [[direct current]] [[extra low voltage]] (DC ELV), and this is used especially for lighting as well as for DC appliances. An [[inverter]] is used to generate AC [[low voltage]], which more typical appliances can be used with.
[[File:Depuradora de Lluc.JPG|320px|thumb|right|A typical stand-alone [[solar PV system]] at a sewage treatment plant in [[Santuari de Lluc]], Spain]]
Stand-alone [[photovoltaic power systems]] are independent of the [[utility grid]] and may use solar panels only or may be used in conjunction with a diesel generator, a wind turbine or batteries.<ref name=source>{{cite web|url=http://www.renewable-energy-sources.com/2010/04/20/stand-alone-photovoltaic-systems/|title=Stand-Alone Photovoltaic Systems|publisher=renewable-energy-sources.com|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713082559/http://www.renewable-energy-sources.com/2010/04/20/stand-alone-photovoltaic-systems/|archivedate=2011-07-13|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trisanita.org/jases/asespaper2010/ases09v5n1y2010.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001412/http://www.trisanita.org/jases/asespaper2010/ases09v5n1y2010.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-04-26|title=A STAND-ALONE PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM, CASE STUDY: A RESIDENCE IN GAZA|publisher=trisanita.org|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=}}</ref>
== Types == <!-- [[Image:PV-system log cabin.png|280px|thumb|right|A schematic of a direct-coupled system, consisting (from left to right) of PV module, battery, inverter, and AC load]] --> The two types of stand-alone photovoltaic power systems are direct-coupled system without batteries and stand alone system with batteries.
=== Direct-coupled system === The basic model of a direct coupled system consists of a solar panel connected directly to a dc load. As there are no battery banks in this setup, energy is not stored and hence it is capable of powering common appliances like fans, pumps etc. only during the day. [[MPPT]]s are generally used to efficiently utilize the Sun's energy especially for electrical loads like positive-displacement water pumps. Impedance matching is also considered as a design criterion in direct-coupled systems.<ref name=source/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eai.in/ref/ae/sol/cs/tech/saps/stand_alone_solar_pv_systems.html|title=Stand Alone PV Systems|publisher=eai.in|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=}}</ref>
=== Stand alone system with batteries === [[Image:PV-system country home1.png|thumb|Schematic of a stand-alone PV system with battery and charger]] In stand-alone photovoltaic power systems, the electrical energy produced by the photovoltaic panels cannot always be used directly. As the demand from the load does not always equal the solar panel capacity, battery banks are generally used. The primary functions of a storage battery in a stand-alone PV system are: * '''Energy Storage Capacity and Autonomy''': To store energy when there is an excess is available and to provide it when required. * '''Voltage and Current Stabilization''': To provide stable current and voltage by eradicating transients. * '''Supply Surge Currents''': to provide surge currents to loads like motors when required.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.localenergy.org/pdfs/Document%20Library/Fundamentals%20of%20batteries%20and%20charge%20control.pdf|title=SBatteries and Charge Control in Stand-Alone Photovoltaic Systems-Fundamentals and Application|publisher=localenergy.org|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=}}</ref>
==Hybrid system== {{See also|Hybrid power|Hybrid renewable energy system|Solar hybrid power system|Wind hybrid power system}}
The ''hybrid power plant'' is a complete electrical power supply system that can be easily configured to meet a broad range of remote power needs. There are three basic elements to the system - the power source, the [[Battery (electricity)|battery]], and the power management center. Sources for [[hybrid power]] include [[wind turbine]]s, [[diesel engine]] generators, thermoelectric generators and [[solar PV system]]s. The battery allows autonomous operation by compensating for the difference between power production and use. The power management center regulates power production from each of the sources, controls power use by classifying loads, and protects the battery from service extremes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Badwal|first1=Sukhvinder P. S.|last2=Giddey|first2=Sarbjit S.|last3=Munnings|first3=Christopher|last4=Bhatt|first4=Anand I.|last5=Hollenkamp|first5=Anthony F.|title=Emerging electrochemical energy conversion and storage technologies|journal=Frontiers in Chemistry|date=24 September 2014|volume=2|doi=10.3389/fchem.2014.00079|pmid=25309898|pmc=4174133}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ginn|first1=Claire|title=Energy pick n’ mix: are hybrid systems the next big thing?|url=https://blog.csiro.au/energy-pick-n-mix-hybrid-systems-next-big-thing/|website=www.csiro.au|publisher=CSIRO|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
== System monitoring == Monitoring photovoltaic systems can provide useful information about their operation and what should be done to improve performance, but if the data are not reported properly, the effort is wasted. To be helpful, a monitoring report must provide information on the relevant aspects of the operation in terms that are easily understood by a third party. Appropriate performance parameters need to be selected, and their values consistently updated with each new issue of the report. In some cases it may be beneficial to monitor the performance of individual components in order to refine and improve system performance, or be alerted to loss of performance in time for preventative action. For example, monitoring battery charge/discharge profiles will signal when replacement is due before downtime from system failure is experienced.<ref name=iea>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=9&eID=dam_frontend_push&docID=377|title=Guidelines for Monitoring Stand-Alone Photovoltaic Systems: Methodology and Equipment|publisher=iea-pvps.org|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=}}</ref>
=== IEC standard 61724 === IEC has provided a set of monitoring standards called the "Standard for Photovoltaic system performance monitoring" ([[IEC 61724]]). It focusses on the photovoltaic system's electrical performance and it does not address hybrids or prescribe a method for ensuring that performance assessments are equitable.<ref>{{cite journal|year=1998|title=Photovoltaic system performance monitoring – Guidelines for measurement, data exchange and analysis|journal=IEC standard 61724, Geneva|pages=37}}</ref>
== Performance assessment == Performance assessment involves: * Data collection, which is a straightforward process of measuring parameters. * Evaluation of that data in a manner that provides useful information. * Dissemination of useful information to the end user.<ref name=iea/>
== Load related problems == The wide range of load related problems identified are classified into the following types: * ''Wrong selection'': Some loads cannot be used with stand-alone PV systems. * ''House wiring'': Inadequate or low quality wiring and protection devices can affect the system's response. * ''Low efficiency'': Low efficiency loads may increase energy consumption. * ''Stand-by loads'': Stand-by mode of some loads waste energy. * ''Start-up'': High current drawn by some loads during start-up Current spikes during the start-up can overload the system temporarily. * ''Reactive power'': The circulating current can differ from the current consumed when capacitive or inductive loads are used. * ''Harmonic distortion'': Non-linear loads may create distortion of the inverter waveform. * ''Mismatch between load and inverter size'': When a higher rated inverter is used for a lower capacity load, overall efficiency is reduced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=9&eID=dam_frontend_push&docID=375|title=Use of appliances in Stand-Alone PV Power supply systems: problems and solutions|publisher=iea-pvps.org|accessdate=2011-07-21|work=}}</ref>
== Gallery ==

[[File:Three-brush dynamo, circuit (Autocar Handbook, 13th ed, 1935).jpg|thumb|300px|Three-brush dynamo charging circuit]] A '''third brush dynamo''' was a type of [[dynamo]], an [[electrical generator]], formerly used for [[car battery|battery]] charging on [[motor vehicle]]s. It was superseded, first by a two-brush dynamo equipped with an external [[voltage regulator]], and later by an [[alternator (automotive)|alternator]].
==Construction== As the name implies, the machine had three [[Brush (electric)|brushes]] in contact with the [[Commutator (electric)|commutator]]. One was [[Ground (electricity)|earthed]] to the frame of the vehicle and another was connected (through a reverse-current cut-out) to the live terminal of the vehicle's battery. The third was connected to the [[field coil|field winding]] of the dynamo. The other end of the field winding was connected to a switch which could be adjusted (by inserting or removing resistance) to give "low" or "high" charge. This switch was sometimes combined with the vehicle's light switch so that switching on the headlights simultaneously put the dynamo in high charge mode.
==Disadvantages== The third brush dynamo had the advantage of simplicity but, by modern standards, it gave poor voltage regulation. This led to short battery life as a result of over-charging or under-charging.
==See also== * [[Amplidyne]] * [[Metadyne]]
==References== * [http://www.ytmag.com/articles/artint4.htm Third Brush Generators] - Yesterday's Tractors website

{{Infobox artist | name = Vasile Adam | image = | caption = | nationality = [[Romanians|Romanian]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1956|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Nisporeni]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = furniture and orthodox icon maker, teacher | known_for = [[Woodcarving]] | notable_works = [[Romanian People's Salvation Cross]] (partially) | awards = [[Order of Saints Peter and Paul]] 1st Grade | website = www.vasileadam.info.md }}
'''Vasile Adam''' (born October 10, 1956 in the [[Soviet Union]]), in little town, [[Nisporeni]]) is Moldovan woodcarver known for furniture-making and icons.
His works are mostly traditional woodworking. Artist has a workshop (from 1996) in his native town in which he provide integrated courses of the woodcarving. Also Vasile Adam works predominantly for private clients. His creations and projects are spread among national collections as well as international ones.
Major works of the artist was donated to chapel of [[Romanian People's Salvation Cross]] and to monastery 'Ciuflea' located in [[Chisinau]].<ref>[http://www.ziarulnational.md/nisporeni-parintele-sfintilor „Părintele” sfinților], newspaper "Ziarul național"</ref>
In his career, the woodworker tried different techniques and traditions in art, including sculpture. One of his stone creations is a monument to the Soviet heroes, who have died during the World War II. The monument rises over the German town Templin.
Adam is a member of [[Handicraftsmen's union of Moldova]]<ref>[http://www.handicrafts.md/en/wood-carving/adam-vasile Artist's profile on Official page of Handicraftsmen's union of Moldova]</ref> and Academy of Traditional Arts (Sibiu, [[Romania]])
==Selected works== <gallery> File:Saint Ylie.jpg|Saint Ylie File:Saint Nicholas. Wood.jpg|Saint Nicholas File:Jesus Christ.jpg|Jesus Christ among lambs File:Outdoor wooden crucifix.jpg|Outdoor wooden crucifix File:First works.jpg|First creations </gallery>
==See also== [[Romanian People's Salvation Cross]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[File:Vestas V164.jpg|thumb|Prototype V164 turbine mounted onshore.]] The '''Vestas V164''' is a three-bladed offshore [[wind turbine]], produced by [[Vestas]], with a [[nameplate capacity]] of up to 10 [[megawatt|megawatts]], a [[Wind turbine#Records|world record]].<ref name="mhiv2017">{{cite web|url=http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/mhi-vestas-launches-the-first-10-mw-wind-turbine-in-history/|title=MHI Vestas Launches the First 10 MW Wind Turbine in History|last=|first=|date=25 September 2018|website=MHI Vestas|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180928080319/http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/mhi-vestas-launches-the-first-10-mw-wind-turbine-in-history/|archive-date=28 September 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref> Vestas revealed the V164's design in 2011 with the first prototype unit operated at [[Østerild Wind Turbine Test Field|Østerild]] in northern [[Denmark]] in January 2014.<ref>http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/v164-8-0-mw-breaks-world-record-for-wind-energy-production/</ref> The first industrial units were installed in 2016 at [[Burbo Bank Offshore Wind Farm|Burbo Bank]], off the west coast of the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=burbo>{{citation| url = http://renews.biz/104080/first-8mw-giant-up-burbo-2/| title = First 8MW giant up at Burbo 2| date = 8 September 2016| work = renews.biz}}</ref><ref>http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/mhi-vestas-offshore-wind-receives-breakthrough-first-order-for-the-v164-8-0-mw/</ref>
==Specifications== Since 2014<ref name=10big2014-02>{{cite web |url=http://www.windpowermonthly.com/10-biggest-turbines |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140209120137/http://www.windpowermonthly.com/10-biggest-turbines |title=10 big wind turbines |publisher=[[Windpower Monthly]] |date=|accessdate=2 March 2017 |archivedate=9 February 2014}}</ref> this offshore turbine has had the [[List of most powerful wind turbines|largest power generation capacity]],<ref name=10big2016>{{cite web |url=http://www.windpowermonthly.com/10-biggest-turbines |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161102095308/http://www.windpowermonthly.com/10-biggest-turbines |title=10 big wind turbines |author=Shaun Campbell |publisher=[[Windpower Monthly]] |date=26 July 2016 |accessdate=2 March 2017 |archivedate=2 November 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> with diameter of rotor {{convert|164|m}} and swept area {{convert|21,124|m2}}. Each blade weighs 33<ref>{{cite web|url= https://ing.dk/artikel/lm-windpower-bygger-verdens-laengste-vindmoellevinge-185073 |title=LM Windpower bygger verdens længste vindmøllevinge |work=[[Ingeniøren]]|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>-35 tonnes.<ref>[http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/innovations/ Vestas V164-8.0 MW®]</ref><ref>[http://nozebra.ipapercms.dk/Vestas/Communication/Productbrochure/V16480MW/V16480MW/ V164 8.0MW]</ref>
Originally called the Vestas V164-7.0MW, at 7.0 MW, the output was increased to 8.0 MW,<ref>[http://www.vestas.com/Admin/Public/Download.aspx?file=Files%2fFiler%2fEN%2fPress_releases%2fV164-7_0_MW_pressconference.pdf A new era for offshore wind power: Presenting Vestas’ V164 – 7.0 MW Turbine for Offshore Power Plants] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911162405/http://www.vestas.com/Admin/Public/Download.aspx?file=Files%2fFiler%2fEN%2fPress_releases%2fV164-7_0_MW_pressconference.pdf |date=September 11, 2013 }}</ref> later to 9.0 MW.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sciencealert.com/monster-wind-turbine-sets-a-new-record-for-energy-output|title=This Monster Wind Turbine Just Set a New Record for Energy Output|last=Nield|first=David|website=ScienceAlert|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref> In 2017 the turbine capacity was upgraded to 9.5 MW.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/worlds-most-powerful-available-wind-turbine-gets-major-power-boost/|title=The world's most powerful available wind turbine gets major power boost {{!}} MHI Vestas Offshore|last=|first=|date=|website=MHI Vestas|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 November 2017}}</ref> The next largest wind turbines and competitors to the V164 are the [[Siemens Wind Power]] SWT-8.0-154 and [[Areva Wind#Technology|Adwen AD 8-180]] offshore turbines with a rated capacity of 8 MW.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.offshorewind.biz/2016/07/05/siemens-rolls-out-8mw-wind-turbine/ |title=Siemens Rolls Out 8MW Wind Turbine|work=Offshore Wind |date=5 July 2016|accessdate=22 February 2017}}</ref><!--Samsung, Adwen? Generator size versus rotor size? --> The [[Enercon E-126]]<!--barely notable--> turbine is rated up to 7.58 MW, but only installed onshore.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rechargenews.com/wind/868311/were-not-afraid-of-offshore-but-we-decided-to-put-150-percent-into-onshore |title='We're not afraid of offshore, but we decided to put 150% into onshore'|work=Recharge |orig-year=2015 |date=2016|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref><ref name=10big2016/>
Starting November 2013, a prototype was installed at Østerild test station. The bottom tower sections weighs over 200 [[tonne]]s and is 24 meters long and 7 meters in diameter. The nacelle weighs 390 tonnes. The turbine weighs 1,300 tonnes and the foundation weighs 4,000 tonnes. The total height is {{cvt|220|m}}.<ref>Morten Kyndby Holm & Ole Iversen. "[http://www.nordjyske.dk/nyheder/verdens-stoerste-vindmoelle-paa-vej/9f451b39-e0e7-4296-bd45-ff4329401aef/112/1513 World's biggest turbine on the way]" ''Nordjyske.dk'' 26 November 2013. Accessed: 26 November 2013.</ref> It became operational in January 2014.<ref>Wittrup, Sanne. "[http://ing.dk/artikel/saa-producerer-vestas-gigantmoelle-stroem-165903 Power from Vestas' giant turbine]" (in Danish. [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=da&sl=da&tl=en&prev=_dd&u=http%3A%2F%2Fing.dk%2Fartikel%2Fsaa-producerer-vestas-gigantmoelle-stroem-165903 English translation] ). ''[[Ingeniøren]]'', 28 January 2014. Accessed: 28 January 2014.</ref> Later that year favourable winds allowed it to sustain its rated 8 MW power for 24 hours for a record one-day production of 192 [[MWh]].<ref>"[http://www.offshorewind.biz/2014/10/17/mhi-vestas-8-mw-turbine-breaks-world-record/ MHI Vestas 8 MW Turbine Breaks World Record]" ''Offshorewind.biz'', 17 October 2014.</ref> In 2017 the 9 MW version did the same for a new one-day production record of 216 MWh.<ref>"[http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/new-24-hour-record/ World’s most powerful wind turbine once again smashes 24 hour power generation record as 9 MW wind turbine is launched]" "IWR.de", 30 January 2017.</ref>
At the September 2018 [[WindEurope|Global Wind Summit]], [[MHI Vestas]] announced the V164-10.0 MW, the world's first double digit offshore wind turbine. The increase in performance was achieved through "a small design change to enhance airflow and increase cooling in the converter". It is not expected to be available for commercial installation until 2021.<ref name="mhiv2017" />
== Notable sites == [[File:Vestas V164 Fawley Site.jpg|thumb|Vestas V164 blades at the disused Fawley Power Station site awaiting painting and finishing.]]
=== United Kingdom: Burbo Bank Offshore Wind Farm === The model was shifted from prototype to production in 2014, when [[DONG Energy]] ordered 32 turbines (256 MW) for the extension of the 90 MW [[Burbo Bank Offshore Wind Farm]]. The nacelles were produced at the former [[Odense Steel Shipyard]], while the blades are made at Vestas' [[Isle of Wight#Industry and agriculture|Isle of Wight facilities]]. Assembly took place in [[Belfast]].<ref name=ing-burbo>Bredsdorff, Magnus. "[http://ing.dk/artikel/nu-indleder-vestas-serieproduktion-af-verdens-stoerste-havmoelle-173154 Nu indleder Vestas serieproduktion af verdens største havmølle]" ''[[Ingeniøren]]'', 22 December 2014. Accessed: 24 December 2014.</ref><ref>[http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/101257/artikel.html Børsen]</ref><ref>[http://www.dongenergy.com/da/presse/nyhedsrum/koncernmeddelelser-detaljer?omxid=792828 DONG PR]</ref> Installation began in 2016<ref name=burbo/> and the wind farm was commissioned in April 2017.
=== Belgium: Norther N.V. Wind Farm === In December 2016, [[Norther Wind|Norther N.V.]] (Eneco/ Elicio) announced that MHI Vestas Offshore Wind will provide 44 x V164-8.4 MW (totalling approximately 370 MW) wind turbines to [[Wind power in Belgium|Belgium’s]] largest offshore wind project, located in the Belgian North Sea, approximately 23 km off the coast of Zeebrugge.<ref>{{cite web|title=World’s most powerful wind turbine selected for Belgium’s largest offshore wind park|url=http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/norther-foi/|website=MHI Vestas Offshore Wind|accessdate=20 February 2017}}</ref>
=== Belgium: Northwester 2 Wind Farm === In April 2018, Parkwind and MHI Vestas announced that MHI Vestas Offshore Wind will provide 23 x V164-9.5 MW wind turbines. Both companies attribute the fast installation timetable, set for late 2019, to the industrialisation of offshore wind in Belgium.<ref>http://www.mhivestasoffshore.com/parkwind-and-mhi-vestas-join-forces/</ref>
=== Denmark: Esbjerg, Måde === In April 2016, two turbines were inaugurated in Måde, each providing 8 MW power for a total of 16 MW. These turbines are series 0, i.e. a pre-mass-production model that may allow for further improvements in the design.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.windpower.org/da/aktuelt/aktuelt_i_vindmoelleindustrien/news_q2_2016/v164_vindmoeller_indviet_i_esbjerg.html|title=V164 vindmøller indviet i Esbjerg |website=www.windpower.org|language=da |trans-title= V164 wind turbines inaugurated in Esbjerg |date= 2016-04-28 |access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref>
=== Denmark: Horns Rev 3 === In 2014, [[Danish Energy Agency]] announced that MHI Vestas Offshore Wind will provide 49 x V164-8.3 MW (totalling 406.7 MW) wind turbines to the farm [[Horns_Rev|Horns Rev 3]], located in the Danish North Sea, approximately 40 km from Esbjerg. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.4coffshore.com/windfarms/horns-rev-3-denmark-dk19.html|title=Horns Rev 3 Offshore Wind Farm|website=http://www.4coffshore.com|language=en |date= 2016-04-28 |access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Østerild Wind Turbine Test Field]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{Orphan|date=December 2016}}
'''Vortex Bladeless S.L''' is a Spanish tech startup that developed a multi-patented wind turbine without blades. In 2014, Vortex Bladeless won The South Summit Award in the category of energy and industry for the best project.
== History == Vortex Bladeless S.L is a wind energy Spanish startup that was founded in 2013 by David Yáñez, David Suriol and Raúl Martín, exclusively dedicated to the development and marketing of Vortex.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":3"/> This multi-patented wind turbine without blades is able to capture the kinetic wind energy by 'vortex shedding' and transform it into electricity.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/vortex-bladeless-wind-energy-project-team-receives-altair-cae-suite-donation-300247351.html|title=Vortex Bladeless Wind Energy Project Team Receives Altair CAE Suite Donation|last=Altair|website=www.prnewswire.com|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref><ref name=":3"/> The idea emerged in 2002 when David Yáñez, the inventor, saw a video of the [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)|Tacoma Narrows Bridge disaster]] and led him to the idea of a bladeless wind turbine.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://amagazine.com.au/stylish-sustainability-out-of-spain/|title=Smart sustainability out of Spain|date=2015-10-02|newspaper=A Magazine|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> This new technology seeks to overcome issues related to traditional wind turbines such as maintenance, amortization, noise, environmental impact, logistics, and visual aspects.<ref name=":3" /> In April 2015, Vortex relocated to Boston and formed a coalition with representatives from Harvard University, IDEO, TerraForm Power and Dat Venture.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vortexbladeless.com/blog.php|title=Vortex|last=vortexbladeless|website=Vortex Bladeless|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/billtucker/2015/05/07/wind-power-without-the-mills/#6f2e68e025ee|title=Wind Power Without The Mills|last=Tucker|first=Bill|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> The improvement of its product has been funded by Repsol Foundation Grant, Spanish Angels Investors and a loan from the Spanish government.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.repsol.com/es_es/corporacion/prensa/Newsletter/proyecto-vortex.aspx|title=Conoce mejor a dos de los ganadores: Proyecto Vortex - repsol.com|website=www.repsol.com|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> Vortex also launched a crowdfunding campaign on June 1, 2015 to fund part of its commercialization.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/vortex-bladeless-a-wind-generator-without-blades--3#/|title=Vortex Bladeless: a wind generator without blades|website=Indiegogo|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> Currently, the company's focus is on the development of small wind products, with mass power generation devices planned for the future.<ref name=":3" />
== Vortex Bladeless Technology/Products == Vortex's innovation comes from its unusual shape, where a [[fiberglass]] and [[Carbon fibers|carbon fiber]] mast oscillates in the wind taking advantage of the [[vortex shedding]] effect.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /> At the bottom of the mast a carbon fiber rod moves inside a [[linear alternator]] that generates the electricity, with no moving parts in contact.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.engineering.com/Library/ArticlesPage/tabid/85/ArticleID/10223/Vortex-Bladeless-Generates-Power-from-Wind-without-Blades.aspx|title=Vortex Bladeless Generates Power from Wind without Blades > ENGINEERING.com|last=ENGINEERING.com|website=www.engineering.com|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.powermag.com/new-approach-powers-bladeless-wind-turbine/|title=New Approach Powers Bladeless Wind Turbine|last=Patel|first=Sonal|date=July 1, 2015|work=|publisher=Power Magazine|access-date=June 27, 2018|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref> Vortex has a small [[carbon footprint]], is noiseless, has low center of gravity and allows for small foundation dimensions, so more generators can be placed in an area, at twice the density of traditional turbines.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=|title=Vortex bladeless wind energy project team receives altair CAE suite donation.|last=|first=|date=2016|work=|publisher=Diario La Razón|via=ProQuest}}</ref>
Vortex Bladeless is working three different products. The main characteristics of the three products are:<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://herox.com/news/354-the-vortex-bladeless-wind-turbine|title=The Vortex Bladeless Wind Turbine|website=herox.com|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> * Vortex Atlantis: 3 meters height and 100W generation capacity, working along with solar panels, mainly to bring energy to an off grid locations.<ref name=":1" /> * Vortex Mini: 13 meters height and 4 kW generation capacity, mainly for small-scale/residential wind.<ref name=":7" /> * Vortex Grand: 150 meters height and 1MW generation capacity, capable of generating electricity for 400 houses.<ref name=":7" /> Atlantis and Mini models are planned to be introduced for private homes in developing countries, or small constructions like radio antennas with their first field tests in Avila, Spain. And by 2018, with help of crowd funding, the deployment of the Vortex Grand.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/jun/01/can-bladeless-wind-turbines-mute-opposition|title=Can bladeless wind turbines mute opposition?|last=Bates|first=Dominic|date=2015-06-01|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref>
== Awards == Vortex Bladeless has won The Latin American Entrepreneurship Award in 2011, Fondo de Emprendedores Fundación Repsol Award in 2012, The South Summit Award in 2014 (in the category of energy and industry), ‘Caja de Ingenieros’ Entrepreneurs Award in 2014 and “Renovable del Año 2016“ Award of the 10th 'Abulenses' phase of Energy, in 2016.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ingenieros.es/noticias/ver/el-aerogenerador-sin-aspas-de-vortex-bladeless-premio-renovable-del-ano/6368|title=El aerogenerador sin aspas de Vortex Bladeless, Premio Renovable del Año|newspaper=Ingenieros|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External Links== * [https://vortexbladeless.com/es/ Official page of Vortex Bladeless.] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VgDF8jzc7TU Vídeo about this wind turbine development and fabrication.]

{{Distinguish | Waist–hip ratio}} A person's '''waist-to-height ratio''' ('''WHtR'''), also called '''waist-to-stature ratio''' ('''WSR'''), is defined as their [[waist]] circumference divided by their height, both measured in the same units. The WHtR is a measure of the distribution of [[body fat]]. Higher values of WHtR indicate higher risk of obesity-related cardiovascular diseases; it is correlated with [[abdominal obesity]].{{cite journal|authors=CM Lee, Huxley RR, Wildman RP, Woodward M|title=Indices of abdominal obesity are better discriminators of cardiovascular risk factors than BMI: a meta-analysis'|journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology|volume=61|issue=7|date=July 2008|pages=646–653|pmid=18359190|doi=10.1016/j.jclinepi.2007.08.012}} A 2010 study that followed 11,000 subjects for up to eight years concluded that WHtR is a much better measure of the risk of heart attack, stroke or death than the more widely used [[body mass index]].{{cite journal|title=The predictive value of different measures of obesity for incident cardiovascular events and mortality.|author=Schneider|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism|volume=95|issue=4|year=2010|pages=1777–1785|url=http://jcem.endojournals.org/cgi/content/full/95/4/1777|doi=10.1210/jc.2009-1584|pmid=20130075|display-authors=etal}} However, a 2011 study that followed 60,000 participants for up to 13 years found that [[waist–hip ratio]] (when adjusted for BMI) was a better predictor of ischemic heart disease mortality than WHtR.{{cite journal|last1=Mørkedal|first1=Bjørn|last2=Romundstad|first2=Pål R|last3=Vatten|first3=Lars J.|title=Informativeness of indices of blood pressure, obesity and serum lipids in relation to ischaemic heart disease mortality: the HUNT-II study|journal=European Journal of Epidemiology|volume=26|issue=6|year=2011|pages=457–461|issn=0393-2990|doi=10.1007/s10654-011-9572-7|pmid=21461943|pmc=3115050}} Conversely, WHtR was not a predictor for new-onset diabetes melitus in at least one study.{{cite journal|title=Inability of waist-to-height ratio to predict new onset diabetes mellitus among older adults in Taiwan: A five-year observational cohort study|author=Ren-Jieh Kuo|journal=Archives of Gerontology and Geriatrics|volume=53|issue=1|year=2011|pages=e1-e4|url=http://www.aggjournal.com/article/S0167-4943%2810%2900130-5/abstract|doi=10.1016/j.archger.2010.05.005|display-authors=etal}} A WHtR of over 0.5 is critical and signifies an increased risk; a 2010 systematic review of published studies concluded that "WHtR may be advantageous because it avoids the need for age-, sex- and ethnic-specific boundary values".{{cite journal|title=A systematic review of waist-to-height ratio as a screening tool for the prediction of cardiovascular disease and diabetes: 0·5 could be a suitable global boundary value. |vauthors=Browning Lucy M, etal |journal=Nutrition research reviews|volume=23|issue=02|year=2010|pages=247–69|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?aid=7929311|doi=10.1017/S0954422410000144}} For people under 40 the critical value is 0.5, for people aged 40–50 the critical value is between 0.5 and 0.6, and for people over 50 the critical values start at 0.6.{{cite web
